sentence:
Change in intraocular pressure
Mean IOP and changes in IOP for the first and second phaco-MIGS eyes across postoperative visits are shown in Figure 1A and B.

Open in a new tab
(A) Mean change in intraocular pressure between first and second eye. (B) Mean intraocular pressure between first and second eye.Change in IOP between the first eye at postoperative visits >1 week demonstrated a moderately positive correlation with change in IOP for the second eye at 6 months, as shown in Figure 2A.

In addition to 6 month IOP change in fellow eyes, first eye change in IOP was shown to be moderately correlated with second phaco-MIGS eye IOP at 3 months following both surgeries (R = 0.42; r² = 0.18; P < .01) as shown in Figure 2B.
Mean IOP and changes in IOP for the first and second phaco-MIGS eyes across postoperative visits are shown in Figure 1A and B.
Change in IOP between the first eye at postoperative visits >1 week demonstrated a moderately positive correlation with change in IOP for the second eye at 6 months, as shown in Figure 2A.

In addition to 6 month IOP change in fellow eyes, first eye change in IOP was shown to be moderately correlated with second phaco-MIGS eye IOP at 3 months following both surgeries (R = 0.42; r² = 0.18; P < .01) as shown in Figure 2B.

Change in medications
Mean ocular hypotensive glaucoma medications and change in medications for the first and second phaco-MIGS eye across postoperative visits are shown in Figure 3A and B.

Open in a new tab
(A) Mean change in ocular hypotensive medications between first and second eye. (B) mean ocular hypotensive medications between first and second eye.Correlations between first eye changes in glaucoma medications at all postoperative time points and second eye medication change at 6 months were all significantly correlated (Fig. 4A).
However, correlations between first and second phaco-MIGS eyes changes in glaucoma medications at all identical postoperative visit time points demonstrated a stronger correlation shown in Figure 4B.
Mean ocular hypotensive glaucoma medications and change in medications for the first and second phaco-MIGS eye across postoperative visits are shown in Figure 3A and B.
Correlations between first eye changes in glaucoma medications at all postoperative time points and second eye medication change at 6 months were all significantly correlated (Fig. 4A).
However, correlations between first and second phaco-MIGS eyes changes in glaucoma medications at all identical postoperative visit time points demonstrated a stronger correlation shown in Figure 4B.
Kaplan–Meier survival analysis was used to assess surgical success rates between the fellow eyes (Fig. 5A).
In contrast, the success rate was 70.3% for second eyes, where the first eye was successful, as shown in Figure 5B (P = .002).
